rev.comment: it only virtualizes mac os x on mac computers
rev.diff:
Line 22: Line 22:
'''Oracle VM VirtualBox''' is an [[x86 virtualization]] software package, originally created by [[Germany|German]] software company innotek GmbH, purchased by [[Sun Microsystems]], and now developed by [[Oracle Corporation]] as part of its family of virtualization products. It is installed on an existing host operating system; within this application, additional guest operating systems, each known as a ''Guest OS'', can be loaded and run, each with its own virtual environment.
'''Oracle VM VirtualBox''' is an [[x86 virtualization]] software package, originally created by [[Germany|German]] software company innotek GmbH, purchased by [[Sun Microsystems]], and now developed by [[Oracle Corporation]] as part of its family of virtualization products. It is installed on an existing host operating system; within this application, additional guest operating systems, each known as a ''Guest OS'', can be loaded and run, each with its own virtual environment.
â
Supported host operating systems include [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista]], [[Windows 7]] and [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]]; there is also a port to [[FreeBSD]] (only OSE version).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.freebsd.org/VirtualBox |title=VirtualBox - FreeBSD Wiki |publisher=Wiki.freebsd.org |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> Supported guest operating systems include a small number of versions of [[NetBSD]] and various versions of [[DragonFlyBSD]], [[FreeBSD]], Linux, [[OpenBSD]], [[OS/2 Warp]], Windows, Solaris, [[Haiku (operating system)|Haiku]], [[Syllable Desktop (operating system)|Syllable]], [[ReactOS]] and [[SkyOS]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Guest_OSes |title=Guest_OSes |publisher=VirtualBox |date=2009-06-12 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> The current beta version (3.2) also allows virtualization of Mac OS X 10.6.<ref>http://lifehacker.com/5530521/virtualbox-32-beta-virtualizes-mac-os-x-on-macs</ref>
+
Supported host operating systems include [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista]], [[Windows 7]] and [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]]; there is also a port to [[FreeBSD]] (only OSE version).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.freebsd.org/VirtualBox |title=VirtualBox - FreeBSD Wiki |publisher=Wiki.freebsd.org |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> Supported guest operating systems include a small number of versions of [[NetBSD]] and various versions of [[DragonFlyBSD]], [[FreeBSD]], Linux, [[OpenBSD]], [[OS/2 Warp]], Windows, Solaris, [[Haiku (operating system)|Haiku]], [[Syllable Desktop (operating system)|Syllable]], [[ReactOS]] and [[SkyOS]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Guest_OSes |title=Guest_OSes |publisher=VirtualBox |date=2009-06-12 |accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> The current beta version (3.2) also allows limited virtualization of Mac OS X 10.6.<ref>http://lifehacker.com/5530521/virtualbox-32-beta-virtualizes-mac-os-x-on-macs</ref>
According to a 2007 survey by DesktopLinux.com, VirtualBox was the third most popular software package for running Windows programs on Linux desktops.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.desktoplinux.com/news/NS8454912761.html |title=2007 Desktop Linux Survey results revealed}}</ref>
According to a 2007 survey by DesktopLinux.com, VirtualBox was the third most popular software package for running Windows programs on Linux desktops.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.desktoplinux.com/news/NS8454912761.html |title=2007 Desktop Linux Survey results revealed}}</ref>
